Dear Bradley D Keller:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 11/22/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (f) A dental re-examination must be
obtained at least every 9 months, unless
a greater frequency is indicated.
One of eight open files of youth in foster care placement reviewed contained
periodic dental examination paperwork completed past the 9-month requirement.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (a) Within 30 calendar days from removal
from the home.
Three of fourteen open youth files (8 FC & 6 IL) reviewed contained initial case
service plans completed past the 30 day requirement.

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 10/31/2023, CAP Approved 11/16/2023

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• ILP agreement forms should require a dated signature to verify when they are
being updated/completed/signed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• When face to face in foster home case contact narrative is minimal it is
difficult to determine if quality visits are being completed and, in some cases,
who was met with/spoken with during the visit.
• Independent Living licensing rules apply to all youth living independently,
regardless of contract type (IL, ILP, etc.)
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The CAP
submitted by the agency was in response to the 10/31/2023 licensing inspection
report and was approved on 11/16/23. That CAP addressed 26 violations, seven
of which were policy related and 19 of which were licensing rule related. Twelve of
those rule related violations were repeated during this inspection (9 of which were
subsections of one rule.) Eight of the seventeen repeats have been repeated
during the past two inspections. Four of the violations established this year were
not established in the past two years. The violations which have been consistently
repeated all relate to independent living files; therefore, additional assessment and
corrective action planning will be needed to address those violations.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator reported barriers and systemic factors impacting
compliance were low staffing/applicants, supervisor turnover, and lack of
placement resources for high needs youth resulting in staff spending a lot of time
with youths in person as well as attempting to locate placement. Areas in which
compliance was impacted were timeliness of reports and paperwork completion.

Financial Overview
The chief administrator provided the agency budget as well as an independent
auditor's statement related to the consolidated financial statements. No financial
concerns were identified.
Staff Interviews
The staff interviewed all reported positive experiences working at the agency. One
staff did state her caseload felt overwhelming at times; however, she stated she
has always remained within the required caseload size. All of the staff reported
consistent and supportive supervision.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency appears to have sufficient space and equipment to provide for the
delivery of foster care, adoption, independent living, and foster home certification
services. Closed adoption files and physical CHRI are stored securely in separate
locked locations preventing unauthorized access. A cross shredder was observed
on-site.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
